abstract.p: Hartt School Associate Prof James Sellars letter holds Bernard Holland fails to mention, in July 2 article, that valid musical culture must include contemporary music (S)

block.p: Bernard Holland's astute article ''A Cult of Comparison and a Musical Glut'' [July 2] is so brave and on the mark that I have to write and applaud it. I cannot count how many times I have been to a dinner party of music lovers who play the same work in recording after recording, asking me which is superior. Which singer's high B-flat or which conductor's tempo is more satisfying to a given listener is no basis for a musical culture. Mr. Holland fails to mention, however, that a valid musical culture must include the music of our time. If only we could, as in the old days, listen to a new piece and respond to its relevance to our times, its quality and craftsmanship; then music would regain its position as one of the arts worth discussion, in critiques or in conversation during a concert intermission. Not until the music itself becomes the basis for our musical response will we have a musical culture worth continuing. And then, perhaps, the record companies would feel the need to document an art that is alive and valid.
The writer is an associate professor of composition and theory at the Hartt School.
